arguments.claim: Substantial prejudice from conviction under s.300/488 instead of s.299/488 as may entitle to compensation
arguments.court_reasoning: appellant invited interference; fine reduced; civil remedy separate; no trial prejudice or misled defence

arguments.claim: Prosecution beyond time considering additional evidence adduced at appellate stage
arguments.court_reasoning: additional evidence puts matter beyond doubt that complaint lodged in time

holdings.text: The additional evidence placed before the Court puts the matter beyond all reasonable doubt that the complaint had been lodged in time before the relevant authority.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Additional evidence adduced pursuant to High Court remand order conclusively shows complaint instituted within three months limitation under s.534.

holdings.text: The alteration of the conviction from s. 299 to s. 300, read with s. 488 of the Act, was no alteration in the substance of the accusation but only in the section more properly applicable to the facts found. There was, therefore, no illegality in the alteration of the conviction under one section to the other.

anchor.surface_text: In the case in hand, it is manifest that the facts sought to be proved and found by the courts below remained the same even after the alteration of the conviction from s. 299 to s. 300, read with s. 488 of the Act. There was, therefore, no illegality

holdings.reasoning_summary: Facts proved remain the same; alteration only corrects section to match compound wall encroachment; authorised by CrPC ss.236/237 and Begu v. King-Emperor precedent.

holdings.text: It is the substance and not the form of the notice that has to be regarded. [...] notwithstanding the label given to the notice, the requisition had been lawfully made in the sense that the appellant had made the encroachment complained of, and that the Municipality was entitled to call upon him to remove the encroachment.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, this argument has only to be stated to be rejected. It is the substance and not the form of the notice that has to be regarded. The effective part of the notice quoted above, leaves nodoubt in the mind of the parties concerned

holdings.reasoning_summary: Effective part of notice clearly requires removal of compound wall encroachment on road-side land; heading under s.299 irrelevant as substance invokes s.300; appellant received and failed to comply.

holdings.text: There was [no] substantial prejudice to the appellant [from alteration to s.300/488]; the prejudice must have reference to any irregularity in the trial of the case. [...] Nor has he been able to show that he was misled as a result of any such technical error.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Appellant invited High Court interference; fine reduced; compensation claim civil remedy unaffected; no trial irregularity, no deprivation of defence opportunity, no misleading.

holdings.text: In view of these considerations, it must be held that there is no merit in this appeal.
holdings.reasoning_summary: All contentions rejected on limitation, notice validity, conviction alteration, and prejudice.

anchor.surface_text: A similar question was raised before their Lordships of the Judicial Committee of the Privy Council in the case of Begu v. The King-Emperor 1 . It was argued before their Lordships that the companyviction of the appellants before the Judicial Committee under s. 201, Indian Penal Code, without a charge under that section, was a serious departure from the procedure laid down in the Code of Criminal Procedure. In that case the initial companyviction was for murder under s. 302 of the Indian Penal Code, but the High Court had set aside that companyviction and substituted a companyviction under the lesser s. After discussing the provisions of ss. 236 and 237 of the Code of Criminal Procedure, their Lordships made the following observations which fully companyer the present companytroversy A man may be companyvicted of an offence, although there has been numbercharge in respect of it, if the evidence is such as to establish a charge that might have been made.

precedents.cited_proposition: A conviction under a different section is permissible if the evidence establishes the offence, even without a specific charge, under sections 236 and 237 of the Code of Criminal Procedure
precedents.cited_holding: A man may be convicted of an offence, although there has been no charge in respect of it, if the evidence is such as to establish a charge that might have been made.
